dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN SCHWIMMER, a drama critic, asleep on his bed. He wears a sleep mask. 2 The bed is a mattress on a makeshift platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers strewn on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exercise bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desk with and old manual typewriter, reference works, periodicals, Styrofoam cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cast-off sofa with pants, shirts, sweater, underwear an socks tossed haphazardly on the cushions and arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A counter that sets apart the kitchen area. A portable TV on the counter. The remains of dinner for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of stacked cardboard boxes with mail spilling out o the floor. Boxes are labeled in crayon: HATE MAIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coffee table with a candle nub in a saucer and six glea rounds of ammunition scattered next to a Llama Comanche . Magnum with a checkered walnut stock -- overall length, n and a quarter inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Port-O-San toilet, about seven feet high, orange, scarr and dented -- scavenged from a construction site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snapshot on the bedside table. It's a blurry picture of Steven holding a cat. Steven wears a peaked cap, and a sh falls across his face. Next to the picture is a clock rad which comes on with a buzz as the clock shows nine AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RADIO ANNOUNCER begins to speak --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Traffic flowing smoothly on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deegan right now but if you're lucky enough to have a ticket for tonight's game, be sure to leave early because it's going to be bumper to bumper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven does not stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: teven's loft is in an old squat building on 47th Street n Twelfth Avenue. The structure looks abandoned. Graffiti everywhere. Entranceway filled with debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day of traffic. Traffic everywhere I look. Cars stop and move and stop again. People sit at the wheel thinking their thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shimmering glass facade of the United Nations Plaza Apartments at 48th Street and First Avenue. A man visible a window on one of the high floors, a cup of coffee in hi hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day in, day out. Red light, green light. Traffic on the major arteries and traffic in the little veins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his POV we see the traffic below creeping along, nea at a standstill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars, vans, taxis, trucks, limos, Mopeds, bikes and buses. Emergency vehicles screaming and wailing. Birth and death, walk and don't walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man takes a sip of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic yesterday, today and tomorrow. Bumper to bumper, soul to soul. This is Lone Eagle over and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 The same man -- the playwright Nicky Rogan with his hand the air, hailing a cab. He is forty-five, vigorous, weari well-made sporty clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a corner of the screen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 Stalled in traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to drive a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you're going, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky glances at the driver's name plate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to drive a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be head of neurosurgery. Big hospital in USSR. This hospital, I'm not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I opened thousands of brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big mess every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved my taxi. Went twelve hours nonstop. Stopped only to pee. I peed under the Manhattan bridge. Peed many times in parks and playgrounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 47th Street and Third Avenue. A man is dancing with a lif size cloth doll. His tape player is on the sidewalk, play and instrumental version of "Beautiful Dreamer" and there a cigar box for donations. A few people look on from a distance. The man wearing an old cutaway, with running sh and the doll has long red tresses and wears a frilly gown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky emerges from a taxi at the corner and walks rapidly past the dancing man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky crosses the courtyard to Buchanan Apartments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 JOANNA BOURNE reaching for the door. Joanna is fifty-ish, handsome, stylishly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 Nicky and Joanna embracing with wordless abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in the hallway clutching each other, stumbling. walls on either side are hung with expensive art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grapple past the living room. Fleeting look at the paintings by Longo and Fischl, a poster by the Guerilla Girls.

dialogues.speaker: T
dialogues.text: he edge of the bedroom. Nicky is crawling into the room a Joanna is hanging on to him, being dragged. They are full dressed except for one of Joanna's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom. A Lichtenstein, a Hockney, a silk-screen of Joanna by Andy Warhol. A Jeff Koons piece. Nicky and Joan roll on the floor until they are halfway under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 Muffled sounds from the bedroom. We track to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid's room. The maid is smoking a cigarette and read New York magazine. The cover is partly obscured by her ha but we can see a blurry black-and-white photo of a man hurrying along a street with a newspaper over his face, shielding himself from the camera. Over the photo, three words visible: THE PHANTOM WHO -- A second line of type i too small to be legible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 Nicky and Joanna are undressing after the fact, very slow and distractedly. Joanna stands by a chair near the windo Nicky is on the other side of the bed and he alternates between standing and sitting as he takes off his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night. Alan Albright called me a handsome woman. Second time he's done that. Son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Alan's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan's very sick. He has to go to New Mexico and sit in a lukewarm solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know about Adele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to her two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently it didn't help. You know about Peter, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Redmond. They found out why he can't remember his lines. There's something living in his brain. A parasite he picked up in Borneo, doing the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he get through it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're watching him closely. There's a special rehearsal set for this afternoon. To bolster his confidence. And that's not all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got bigger problems, Joanna. Personal problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all, Nicky. I've been backing your plays for fifteen years. And I've never been more depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: teven Schwimmer. The most powerful critic in America gets his first crack at Nicky Rogan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY (hiding his concern) Look. All I want is a haircut. I'm not worried about this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA Ever since he started reviewing the Broadway theater, nobody in this business has been worried about anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY They can send their heartless brilliant boy-critic. There's a much bigger thing going on than tonight's opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY The Red Sox

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA You mean the World Series? I thought the Red Sox were winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Three games to two. But if you know their history, you realize there's a tragedy in the making. I've been carrying this franchise on my back since I was six years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA It can't be all that personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna enters the walk-in closet to finish undressing and a nightdress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY If you have a team you've followed all your life, and they raise your hopes and crush them, and lift them and crush them, do you want me to tell you what it's like? It's like feeling your childhood die over and over.     J JOANNA I mean Nicky, really, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky follows her into the closet, still in his shirt and boxer shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA I'm proud of this play. It's so different from anything you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY This is how we've managed to last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA We're able to surprise each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY In and out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA Because we're completely mismatched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY We don't even like each other, do we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky walks out of the closet, takes off his shirt, gets bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA I used to tell myself. Talent is more erotic when it's wasted. Will I see you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY The Red Sox blow a chance to win their first World Series since 1918. You expect me to miss that for an opening night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna emerges from the closet in her nightdress and gets into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA It makes me so mad. Steven Schwimmer ready to strike. The exterminating angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY It's all worked out. They'll lose tonight. Then they'll lose tomorrow. I see it with stunning clarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your best play, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll lose because they're my team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will absolutely hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is just waking up. The radio plays soft music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches over and hits the off button, then activates t cassette player. He struggles out of bed and Sufi music begins to fill the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands at the foot of the bed, a man in his mid-twenti hollow-chested, slightly potbellied, wearing rumpled paja bottoms and a Mostly Mozart T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not remove the sleep mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music has a sensuous, driving beat. Voices begin to chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven holds his arms parallel to the floor. Slowly he be to turn, clockwise. The beat picks up and he whirls more quickly, his mouth coming open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he begins to whirl about the room. The chanting grows intensity. Although he is blindfolded, Steve deftly avoid running into furniture and other objects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven stops whirling at the precise moment the music sto playing. He is back at the foot of the bed, arms stretche wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 Creeping along. Nicky leaning toward the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrapped my sandwiches in tinfoil. I ate and drove. I had one of those big checkered cabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crosstown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very bad today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's nameplate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cleaned out the ashtrays religiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sitting here five years in traffic. It is one continuous traffic since I arrive. Why must it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up alongside. Nicky notices the young woman the rear seat. It is his daughter Laurel. He opens his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel, stay there. (to his driver) Keep the meter running. And try to stay abreast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky leaves his taxi and gets into Laurel's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Nicky pushes in next to her. Laurel is eighteen, slightly overweight, with a pleasant and expressive face. She is carrying books in a nylon haversack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never see you anymore. Where are you all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to college. I thought you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to get some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't drink coffee, Daddy. And this is not what we should be talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What do you want to talk about? I'll talk about anything. What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky lifts a small radio and headset out of her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL I'm seeing your play tonight, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Why do you need a radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL So at the intermission I can listen to the ball game. Do you know that mother is seeing a prominent divorce lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY That's completely crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Don't talk like that. How prominent? What are you implying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL She's doing like those Iranians. `I divorce thee. I divorce thee. I divorce thee'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY (indicating driver) And he hears it the same time I hear it? What happened to family secrets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's nameplate ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Mother is totally, you know, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Abulhassas, we'll be getting out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky pays the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 Nicky stands alongside the first taxi and pays his origin driver. Laurel reluctantly exits the second taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47th Street between First and Second Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky and Laurel enter the coffee shop they are greeted b the owner, a hefty Greek named GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky, you don't come in for a while. Everything's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello George. You're so healthy and thick-bodied I want to punch you in the chest. This is my daughter Laurel. Just to hear the sound it makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your picture in the paper. Two papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means they're getting ready to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I hear. I have four, five actors working here. `His best play since "Yessiree Bob" I'm telling you, they say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads them toward a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Nicky is launched into a full breakfast. Laurel has a tea in a cup -- no water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If lawyers for the mob are called controversial, why are divorce lawyers called prominent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Because they get outstanding settlements. And Mother is determined that this time there's no turning back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I just had breakfast with her. She didn't say a word about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young waiter recognizes Nicky and unobtrusively points out to another waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Because you refuse to believe she's serious. You've always refused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Don't be so steely-eyed. It's that course you're taking in criminology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Oh please. Not now. (beat) She wants you to stop seeing What's- Her-Name. Finally. Now and forever. Do you think that's too much to ask? For a wife of nineteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY You're too young to be studying criminal behavior. It's making you obsessive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL She is kicking you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Your mother and I have something between us that's too strong to damage permanently. Believe me, I know this. That's right, nineteen years. And what about the days and minutes? Sharing small moments, sharing memories, raising a beautiful child. We're wedded in the deepest and strongest ways. Lillian isn't only my wife. She's my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Nicky and Laurel stand on a short line at the cash regist each holding a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother won't tell me how long you've been seeing this person. She's embarrassed to tell me. So why don't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call her Mother all the time. It makes her sound tragic and unforgiving. What happened to Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't turn her into Mother. You did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This person and I are a thing of the total past. I promise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes Laurel's check away from her, intending to pa himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel snatches it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what Mother said to me? Daddy's demons are so intense he doesn't even know he's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Bank towers. The Bank of India, Banco di Napoli, Bear Stearns, the Bank of New York, The Chemical Bank, Manufacturers Hanover. A sense of real institutions loomi over the busy street. The bank names engraved on bronze markers, carved in granite, incised on glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Street level. A glimpse of the bronze statue called "Taxi Park Avenue" -- a man with and attache case and raincoat, hailing a cab. The real people hailing cabs, well-dressed and women striding along with briefcases -- purposeful, successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Nicky rides again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's life, it's taxis. People trying to make contacts, make deals, meet their lovers. Taxis are sexy. You can't have Manhattan without taxis. I was proud of my taxi. I kept my taxi clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky shifts his gaze. He sees Elliot Litvak slinking acr the street, looking faintly unclean and shows a trace of smile. He watches Elliot enter the lobby of the Chemical Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Elliot is at a cash machine, making an elaborate transact

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky appears, approaching the adjacent machine. Elliot s him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky. I was thinking about you. I went to the preview last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky attends to his own transaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) A lovely piece of theater. Small but important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly effective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes his cash and begins to move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't appreciate what they've built for us. We're artists who are too dumb to see that this is the peak moment of Western culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an artist. I'm a craftsman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press a button and they give us money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride with me. We need a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stalled between Park and Madison. The driver has opened t door and is standing just outside the cab, trying to determine the cause of delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) How is Lillian? I haven't seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, finished and done with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds so final. But are we really surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm completely stunned. I don't want this to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't we know it would happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't needle me, Elliot. Tell me how bad you feel. We're suppose to feel bad together. This is what friends do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Joanna Bourne. So rich and crisp. This woman lets you touch her body? You put your hands on her personal parts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky hits Elliot -- a token blow to the arm. Elliot thin about it, then hits back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They swat each other, half kiddingly, each of them leanin away from the other to prevent being hit in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 A whitish brown mist is building the west. There is a sen of scurrying people. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, we must abandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruptured steam pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruptured steam pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asbestos lining. Do not inhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contaminated substance. Very dangerous. Shooting mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not inhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruptured steam pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asbestos lining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not inhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's name plate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky pays him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver flees eastward. Nicky and Elliot run across Madison Avenue. A snowstorm of asbestos is shooting out o man hole cover west of Fifth Avenue, reducing visibility near zero. Cars and people are white shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, with collars raised and hands over heads hur into a restaurant on 47th Street between Madison and Fift 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 A small narrow room. Handsome wall paintings -- a Tuscan town. Very slow day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky and Elliot sitting with a carafe of wine, a bottle mineral water and some bread sticks. Glancing at menus intermittently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to think. When did you start looking so terrible? You look awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you the year, the day, the night, the minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to love life. You don't exude this any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I exude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suffering. You exude a person who sits in a small dark apartment eating soft white bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight you find out what it means to suffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight. What's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. They don't have any carrot soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean because What's-His-Name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will suffer because he is in the theater. And you will suffer a thousandfold when his review appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is just a review. Do not inhale. Very dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the fuss? I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said eighteen months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened eighteen months ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before his Broadway days. He reviewed the one-act I did at the Fulton Fish Market. We did this play at four AM, outdoors in the rain. One performance. For the fish handlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven Schwimmer. I memorized every word of this review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recite it to myself with masochistic relish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY A year and a half later? You're still brooding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patron approaches the table and stares at Nicky with a fixed grin of crazed recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN Yessirree Bob! Yessisree Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky's jaw becomes set and he pours himself a glass of w as the man backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT You don't know about obscure writers, Nicky. How we have our anger to nurture and love. Our murderous fantasies for any amount of fame, money , power and sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress comes by. She is Paisley Porter, attractive, her mid-twenties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAISLEY Guys ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Paisley Porter. I didn't know you were waiting tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAISLEY Elliot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT (to Nicky) This is a great young out-of-work actress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AISLEY Elliot Litvak. Have you been ill? And Mr. Rogan. How nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What's good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAISLEY We have a very nice pasta today. Alla Putanesca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alla puttanesca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nicky) Isn't she great? What did I tell you? A talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26 The food has arrived. Nicky is eating compulsively -- in contrast to Elliot, who sips his mineral water, dabs his mouth with a napkin, looks around the restaurant between bites. When Nicky is finished with his food, he begins picking among the items on Elliot's plate. Elliot uses hi fork to deflect Nicky's fork and the two men have a brief duel with utensils, fencing silently but intently, using knives and spoons to vary action. 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 The asbestos mist still clings. Men in protective suits a masks move slowly, like moon walkers. Halted traffic, abandoned cars. Mud covering the sidewalks and shop windo A gauzy stillness, dreamlike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Stillness. A slow whirling 360-degree shot. The kitchen a is empty. The door of the portable toilet is open and no is inside. The makeshift wardrobe is empty except for fou five hangers with shirts and jackets. There is no one at desk or exercise bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sound, faint but persistent, like an intake of air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom. The toilet bowl has been ripped out and tak away, leaving a hole in the floor. Brownish water drips f the tap into the wash basin, which is indelibly stained. drip makes a two-part sound and it matches the rhythm of intake of air. One-two. Pause. One-two. The bathtub has b sprayed by a graffiti artist. Multi-colored swirls and arabesques.

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: teven is sitting on a mat in the tub, arms in the air and folded so that his fists are close to his ears. He is in lotus position, breathing in serious meditation -- a deep intake of breath followed by a softer expulsion, matching beat of the dripping faucet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is still wearing the sleep mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 The kitchen staff is eating at a group of tables pushed together. Nicky's table has been absorbed by this cluster he sits reading the sports section in a tabloid and havin espresso with his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot, Paisley and actor-waiter stand at the small bar i conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Nicky, two kitchen workers talk about the ball ga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a good feeling about tonight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got Ojeda going. He pitched beautiful last time out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus Darryl's due for a big game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate the Mets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Mets lose, they just lose. It's a flat feeling. But the Red Sox -- here we have a rich history of interesting ways to lose a crucial game. Defeats that keep you awake, that pound in your head like the hammer of fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paisley walks across the room toward the kitchen. Nicky pauses to watch her, then resumes speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can analyze a Red Sox defeat day and night for a month and still uncover layers of complex feelings - - feelings you didn't know you were capable of. The pain has a memory all of it's own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 The parking lot is empty. The stands are empty. A few mem of the crew move the batting cage into place for batting practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 The empty visitor's locker room. Uniforms hang on the doo of the lockers in preparation for tonight's game. We see 3    names Henderson, Stanley, Buckner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 Cramped quarters. Intensely claustrophobic. Elliot at the urinal. Nicky at the hand-dryer. An actor-waiter standing between them at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting Steven Schwimmer) `One thing saves Elliot Litvak's work from complete mediocrity, and this is his lack of ambition.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets funnier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (zipping up) It gets funnier. See, Nicky? They chart the laughs. This from a critic who lives like a fallen monk. Whose address is a carefully guarded secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A critic who has to disguise himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To go to the theater. Wears I don't know what. Make-up, padding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he is so deeply hated by so many people in the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has to disguise himself, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For his own safety and peace of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter squeezes past and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to tell you what it was like, reading that review at the newstand with trucks rumbling past and street vendors facing Mecca?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, `I'm dead'. He killed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 Elliot standing near the front window, in a shaft of sunlight, examining a white after-dinner candy. He puts i his pocket for later.

dialogues.speaker: P
dialogues.text: aisley eating lunch at the end of the long table, looking to see Nicky approach with liqueur and a glass on wine. H sits opposite her, placing the wineglass in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've worked with Elliot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the fish-market play. What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of Steven's finer moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he has finer moments now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has -- something. A funny little quality I find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot wants to kill him with a railroad spike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little drastic maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alla puttanesca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more time.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ENTRANCE WAY
dialogues.text: 34 Elliot watches Nicky embrace Giorgio. Nicky carries the tabloid he'd been reading -- the "Daily News". Elliot and Nicky stand at the door and watch the whitish mist that continues to linger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it safe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we Nought to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not inhale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up their collars and run outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 The street is deserted. Nicky holds the newspaper over hi face for protection. Each man has an arm in the air, tryi to hail a taxi. They are standing near a trash receptacle that carries an advertisement for "New York Magazine". It a reproduction of the cover that we'd glimpsed earlier in Joanna's apartment when her maid was reading the magazine furtive man shielding his face with the newspaper -- and headline about a Phantom. Nicky and Elliot do not see the receptacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus comes down the street with a large horizontal ad covering its right side. It is the same ad -- five of the actually, five "New York Magazine" covers side by side. Elliot is trying to hail a cab and doesn't notice the ad. the bus bears down, Nicky steps out of the way, removing newspaper from his face and getting a clear look at the f photos on the side of the bus -- a man concealing his fac with a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky reads the text under the logo of "New York Magazine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PHANTOM WHO HAUNTS BROADWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learning to hate Steven Schwimmer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky stares after the bus. Another bus comes along, carr the same ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky watches darkly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 This is the diamond district. Store signs reading:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antique Jewelry     We Buy Diamonds     Gold Emporium Wholesale Jewelry       All Brand-Name Watches Reduced

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Nicky is reading the newspaper. The driver is speaking Chinese into his two-way radio. Squawky replies from the dispatcher in machine gun Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man has taken over my mind. He's not only out there. He's in my head and I can't get rid of him. I can't write a word without imagining his response. I'm paralyzed as an artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the problems that artists have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been saying that for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockingly) `I'm just a professional. A dues- playing member of a guild.' Because you're afraid, Nicky. That's the darkest part of you. You don't think you're good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky lowers the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's nameplate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 About a dozen people gathered together including several diamond merchants in their beards, black suits and fur ha They are watching the man in the cutaway dancing with his cloth doll. Someone places a donation in the cigar box. F the tape player: "Dancing in the Dark."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot ends up near the Gotham Book Mart, on the north si of the street. Nicky looks right past him into the bookst window. He sees something that interests him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wait Efor me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the haircut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Nicky walks along the main aisle, looking at a woman stan in the poetry nook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a few people in the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the back room and gets a glimpse of a woman wal through the opposite doorway back into the main room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He squeezes past a browser and looks through the doorway. Someone is just leaving the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the rear of the store, where the office is located. The door is open, the room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He re-enters the main room and sees a woman seated on the step of the stairway that leads to the basement stacks. H back is to Nicky and she is reading a book. He approaches slowly and then squats by the doorway to get a closer loo her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns. It is Paisley Porter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 Nicky and Paisley in a corner of the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep slipping away. How do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was one of those silent, listening children. Glued to the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was all noise. Played the radio loud. Battled constantly with my brother and sister. Here I am, world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear good things about the new play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I. Over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Redmond is an actor I admire enormously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't want to meet some out-of- work ingenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to prolong our afternoon. In case you haven't noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fact is, I have to get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is what true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wears a disguise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven goes to extremes to protect his privacy. No friends. No phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of. Sometimes. You're not building an obsession about Steven, are you? Look. I understand opening- night jitters, but you've got one of the great actors in American theater starring in your play.
47th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Nicky has been cornered just inside the entrance by the s manager, a small, fierce woman named RENEE SIMON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take this anymore. He forgets simple lines. He forgets where to stand. We tell him and tell him and tell him. I know he's a sweet man. I love Peter. It's not his fault. But I've never worked in a show where the leading man has

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4              parasites in his brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 Nicky sits down in the orchestra, looking darkly into spa brooding. He surveys the set, a working class kitchen, be it a backdrop of dark streets and looming tennaments. A portly well-dressed man appears, moving along the row tow Nicky. This is SIDNEY FABRIKANT, the producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: aybe we ought to postpone the opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna loves this play. She has sunk tons of money. She is completely Ncommitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: appreciate that, Sidney. But our leading man can't remember his lines. And his understudy can't carry the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky looks out at the rehearsal in progress on stage. Th director, JACK HASKINS and the actor PETER REDMOND (50)confer, move about gesturing and blocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had lunch with Joanna. She said she told you about Peter. You weren't concerned, she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hat was this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened since? You're worried about this kid who writes these reviews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky looks across the theatre. Paisley Porter sits alone tenth row center, watching rehearsal with rapt attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'm not worried about this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I am. Worried sick. Everybody quotes Steven Schwimmer. He's here to announce the death of civilization. He kills a play every time he farts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postpone. We have every right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. All the elements are in place. Delay the opening and we lose the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had three straight washouts, Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deliciously) You're dangling from the last letter of your last name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actor sitting on the sofa. Nicky on one knee, leaning towards him in intimate conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney remains optimistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney Fabrikant. Our producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was educated by nuns.

dialogues.speaker: Y
dialogues.text: es.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have excellent long-term memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kissed Shirley Felder on the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my parasite is consuming all the new memories. Eating my lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to see the words. Try to build a mental picture of the script. Imagine your lines high- lighted with a felt tip pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your favorite color crayon, growing up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burnt sienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine was cobalt blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your history, isn't it? Nicky? All around us. And my parasite is consuming it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kissed her while she was laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see her face so clearly. Dear God. My heart was flying out of my chest with love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 Jack Haskins and Renee Simon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear he got the parasite in Burma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard Borneo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we blame the Third World for our parasites? Maybe he got it in Denver or Minneapolis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he got it in Borneo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 Nicky and Peter still conferring. Jack and Renee approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel shaky about one line in particular. If I can get past this line. I think I can handle the last long speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which line, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Son says to the Father, This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Father replies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the line I can't ever, for the life of me remember. I just can't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same line. The Father simply repeats what the Son says to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it sounds easy. But something happens between the time I hear the line and the time I'm suppose to Jrepeat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's work on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) Let's work on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Nicky and Paisley Porter make their way out of the theatr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he can do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a very sweet man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone waiting for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a certain kind of wounded young man who uses his oddness to get laid. Is that our Steven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm sleeping with him, and I haven't said I am, then so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) So everything. That's so what. So I begin to hate him. So I want to do him grave harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't even know me. How can you care what I do with whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you both. Enough. How much knowledge does it take before a man does something crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to talk about doing crazy things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 They enter lobby daylight, squint a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Come on, Paisley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Steven not only disguises himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the theater armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUTED BACKGROUND VOICES ON THE LOBBY PA: Jack Haskins and Peter Redmond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could Pbe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look up at the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels he has to defend himself if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm actually beginning to enjoy this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide of the theater. Nicky says goodbye to Paisley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverse angle, Elliot watches them from across the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icky goes back inside the theatre. Paisley walks west on 47th street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot waits for a moment, then follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 The Port-O-San. Steven emerges and goes to the stacked cardboard boxes against the wall. His hate mail. He is wearing a bath towel like a prayer shawl over his sweat clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drags one of the boxes to the ratty armchair. He sits the chair by the filthy window that looks west toward the early-setting sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a letter from the box, opens it, reads it, lets fall to the floor. Takes another letter, opens it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven tenses, does not move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves warily toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven, it's me. Will you open please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven releases the dead-bolt lock and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come to me. I wanted to believe you would one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't come to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're here. So you must have come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is back in the chair by the window. Paisley nervou prowls the loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words I never understood until today how much pain and anxiety you've been causing with your reviews. Steven, it's so unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it's unfair. The truth is always unfair. Why do you think I live this way? Hiding out. Stealing electricity from a lamp post. Because people who write the truth are outcasts of society. I can't live openly, in a nice clean doorman building, with my name on the mailbox. They'd come after me in packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you stopped hurting people. Write the truth gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is never gentle. Listen to me carefully. Each of us lives in the thinnest possible wrapping of wishes and dreams. Truth is the force that penetrates this wispy skin. It hurts and maims. ( reaching down to clutch a fistful of letters) Look how they hate me for telling the truth. It's an education, Paisley. The College of Raw Nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN(cont'd) Letters dripping blood. Cries of revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I've seen your victims. One past and one future. I thought I might convince you to reconsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thought, at last, she's here, she wants me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you, Steven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paisley moves towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay. Teach me to be compassionate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going home to my machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 Elliot looks up and sees Paisley emerging from Steven's building. He crosses the street toward her.

dialogues.speaker: W
dialogues.text: hen Paisley sees him, she seems to freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 47th Street between Broadway and Eight Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky walking slowly backwards, arm raised, trying to hai cab. It is getting dark. He glances left, sees a large tw panel poster in front of the theater. One half is a black white photo -- a younger Nicky Rogan, in a tuxedo, holdin award in his raised hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other half is all type --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new Nicky ogan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees someone enter the theater lobby. It is his daught Laurel. He follows, catching up to her at the end of a sh line of people at the ticket window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel. Tickets are all set. I double-checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Daddy. But I just need one. Mother's not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- why should a bitter divorce interfere with tradition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel reaches the window and speaks to the clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rogan, Laurel. You also have a Rogan, Lillian. She won't need it. Sell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it yourself. Take a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a date. I don't want a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave the window with Laurel's ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you blame me. It's because we never talk. Let's talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a class. I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk later? Will you be at the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is out the door, hurrying across the street. Nicky st under the marquee, calling out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find you. After the show. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 Moving very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's nameplate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man is hit the other day by another taxi. I mean he is flying. Crash against the windscreen. Right here in my face. Blood is everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never left the garage without my Windex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was barrister in Kenya. I said to him, get off from here. I cannot drive with your body on my windscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove twelve hours straight through. Ate at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to eat at the wheel. You cannot get anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the drama. We're waiting for life to continue. Where do you pee, Ibrahmin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the Manhattan Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where I peed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 47th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenue. A hotel, a h school, brownstones with fire escapes. 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Michael, Nicky's father, is making an omelette on the old stove. He is pushing eighty, slow-moving, with a two-day stubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael goes to the intercom, inches from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker) Go way. I'll call a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, will you let me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker) Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here. At the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael goes to the door and looks through the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky comes on Sunday's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are your glasses? Go get them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's you, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my way to get a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does Nicky get his hair cut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky stands against the door, speaking softly into the peephole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across Ninth Avenue. Dodgie's. Where you've been getting your hair cut for fifty years. Where Uncle Billy and Uncle Marty got their hair cut. Where Jim Rorty shot a man for cheating at poker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was rummy, not poker. But I'll take a chance and let you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Michael is eating his omelette at a small enamel-topped t in the kitchen. Nicky stands by the boxlike refrigerator, drinking a beer. This is the kitchen that is the centerpi of the theatre set. The new play is Nicky's young life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a constant shock to me, how small this place is. How did we do it? Five people in these little rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get yourself something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes some eggs out of the refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must have been heroic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five's not so many. There were families with seven kids. A grandmother. A dimwit uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lillian says it once a week. `Why doesn't he come live with us?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know the answer to that. Why don't we watch the ball game later? We'll go to Mannion's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're only gonna lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Of course they're gonna lose. We'll watch them lose. What good is heartbreak if we don't experience it firsthand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL The Red Sox are your problem. I never understood about you and the Red Sox. Everybody rooted for the Yankees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is scrambling the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Remember 1949? Last two games of the season. Against the Yankees. The Sox lost on Saturday. Then they lost on Sunday. First I cried for twenty-four hours. Then I had fist- fights the rest of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL It's one thing for kids. You get older, you Nhave other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY It's all connected, Pop. It's one life. Baseball is memory. How do fathers and sons show their love? They go to a ball game together. Thirty-five years later, they sit in the kitchen and remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL But the son is suppose to stop crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I could have grown up happy. A Yankee fan. A divorce lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky sees his father's glasses on a shelf above the stov He puts them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY You'll need these. Tonight. For the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL Don't make me sit through one of your plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Pop. I know you don't like the commotion of opening night. But I especially want you to see this play. It's new territory for me. And for you too. I have to know what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when did that matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not start that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My back is killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your elastic brace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're suppose to wear it when your back gives you trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost it. I lose everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go get you another one. You have to wear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes a roll off the counter, makes a sandwich for scrambled eggs, takes a bite and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back. Take a good look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael puts on his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I know who I'm letting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky leaves the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 The man in the cutaway dances with his doll. The tape mac plays "In The Still of the Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: " The street is completely empty except for the dancer. Nicky, a small paper bag in his hand, reenters his father building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 The room bears some resemblance to the living room set at the Barrymore. Michael sits at the end of the sofa, weary Nicky is taking an athletic bandage -- about four feet lo and three inches wide -- out of the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a chair that is set perpendicular to Michael's of the sofa, so that Nicky is looking at his father in profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Why doesn't he come live with us?' Because everything is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lucky they don't knock down the building. It could happen anytime. And everything worth remembering is right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the building's okay. At least for the time being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't think it was okay when you lived here. You wanted to get out so fast I thought you were running a marathon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normal boy's ambition. I like coming back. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell your friends your father used to work the docks. Callused hands. But you had an attitude when you were growing up that wasn't easy for your mother and me to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is gradually unbuttoning his father's shirt so that can wrap the bandage around the old man's chest and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in a hurry to do big things, make big mistakes. Any mistakes were okay as long as it was big. But I'm trying to see these things clearly and honestly. That's the play they're going to kill starting tonight. There's a guy out there getting ready to rip it apart. And that's us. Who we were and where we come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show him who we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes off the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael struggles out of his T-shirt and we see that he i wearing the elastic bandage he thought he had lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sitting with his head tilted up, eyes closed, and i unaware that he is wearing the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes the new bandage, winds it tightly and puts it back in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father has gone to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 It is dark and cold. Nicky emerges and walks west, diagon across the street, to a barbershop on the other side of N Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lliot is on the stoop waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 Nicky sits in the barber chair. Elliot pulls up a custome chair and sits with his back to the mirror, more or less facing Nicky. The barber, an elderly hawk-eyed man named Dodgie, begins his preparations for Nicky's haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Then you should carry a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places the sheet over Nicky's upper body and fastens i the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I used to carry a gun when I drove a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I gave it away. I thought, I'm a writer now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT That was a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DODGIE You should never be without a gun. In this city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT If he carries a gun, you have to carry a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY We're making too much of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT No, we're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I'm not a lonely spooky writer like you. Nursing a hundred grudges. I'm a man who loves life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT We're talking about something deeper than grudges. How do we respond to personal attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DODGIE In this city? And you don't carry a gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT How do we maintain our dignity and self-respect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY In other words why should we suffer silently at this kind of abuse? The man is out there ruining lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT It's your best play, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY He'll hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT He'll kill it. He'll write a review so devastating it will shatter your career and cause the most unmanageable psychic grief. What happens to your apartment on the East River? Your house in Connecticut, where you watch things grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodgie goes to the cabinet on which the cash register sit He opens the cabinet door, slides out a drawer and remove some hand towels. There is something there he wants Nicky see. An old pockmarked revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky sees the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY We were thinking of putting in a pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT (quoting) `The most interesting thing about Elliot Litvak is that he writes the way he looks -- fuzzy, grubby and shifty-eyed.' (beat) I'm telling you as a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT There are things that speak to us from the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DODGIE In this city you don't walk five feet out the door and there is somebody trying to take what's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Your truth is locked in your past. Find it. Know it for what it is. (beat) Shoot him, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT The American theater doesn't need people like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Shoot him, Nicky. Not that we really mean it. But where does he live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT Keep going west. Last building before the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY How do you Eknow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LLIOT Paisley Porter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT About an hour and a half ago. I saw her come out of a place. She said she was visiting a friend. But she wouldn't tell me who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Had to be him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIOT She was very evasive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky gets out of the chair. Dodgie removes the sheet for and Elliot smooths down his clothes and hair, like a pair grooms attending a warrior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky goes to the cabinet, gets the gun. He returns to th chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I'm enjoying this more every minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot takes an after-dinner candy out of his pocket -- t candy he pocketed in the Italian restaurant after lunch. blows the lint off and eats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you want the sideburns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant and refined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds of people pouring down the ramps from the train station, hurrying, late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The umpire's room -- six men nibbling cookies, smoking a minute cigarette, adjusting equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unidentified room somewhere in there lower reaches of stadium. Twenty cases of Great Western champagne stacked ready for the postgame celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 Steven shaving. He does it symmetrically. A stroke under left sideburn; a stroke under the right sideburn. Left si of jaw; right side of jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven standing in his shorts, applying putty to his jaw make it square. Then a false mustache and a wavy blond hairpiece. Then a thick bronze makeup paste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven in front of a full-length mirror near the bed, put on a bulletproof vest, which gives him a solid appearance bulking his caved-in chest and concealing his pot belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven putting on black trousers, a brash shirt with a br bow tie, which he tips slightly askew. A pair of black an white shoes with elevator heels. Then his shoulder holste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven leaning over the coffee table, inserting bullets i the chamber of the revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the gun in his holster, he stands in front of the mirror. Takes the gun out, aims it, puts it back in the holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does a dazzling karate move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven putting on a metallic rayon sport coat. A long sil scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a handsome, dashing young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts on a pair of dark glasses and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 pening night crowd. The sidewalk is mobbed. Limousines an taxis pulling up. Men in tuxedos, other men scalping tick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV crew with a female reporter doing interviews: talk to Joanna Bourne and Sidney Fabrikant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of ten-year-old break dancers entertain the well heeled opening night crowd. 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuck in traffic. Nicky in the rear seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver is a black woman around fifty. Next to her in front seat is her grandson, Matthew, who is ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the taxi is homelike. A plastic drinking magnetically rooted to the dashboard. A small battery- operated fan next to the cup. The steering wheel is upholstered. There are family photographs on the dashboar and visors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew's schoolbooks are next to him on the front seat. is doing his homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's name plate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved my taxi. A checkered cab. Big and rumbly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking at you trying to think. Put your face in the mirror. I know I recognize you from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody else does. Why not you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Frankie Lazzaro. The gangster from Rhode Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA Matthew, look at him. When I lived in Roxbury, the media followed this man everywhere. He was bigger than ten movie stars. (to Nicky) Where's your white Lincoln limo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is delighted at the mistake and alters his voice slightly, using a gangsterish inflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY (to Matthew) Some little kid stole the hubcaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA The most charming gangster in New England. Where are we going, Mr. Lazzaro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Call me Frankie. And it looks like we're going nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA Might be an accident on the West Side Highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY How come you got the kid with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA Matthew's my grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY A grandmother. God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA He does bless me, each and every day. Matthew's mother works a hospital shift, so I pick him up at school. We stop for a meal usually around this time. He does his homework and gets some experience meeting people. But we never had a famous mobster before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY It's the kid's lucky day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOYOTA This is one charming crook. If shooting people is charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a complicated subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a simple subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we're stuck here front and back. It's dinnertime for you, game time for me. Let's park the cab and go to Mannion's. What do you say, Matthew? We'll drink beer and talk baseball.

dialogues.speaker: GRAINY IMAGE
dialogues.text: 67 Filling the screen. Actual footage. A man in a parachute coming down on an expanse of grass. It is the infield at Stadium. He carries a sign reading "Let's Go, Mets". Secu men hustle the parachutist off the field and into the Met dugout as the game begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 We see that the image is on a TV screen over the bar. The place is crowded, a neighborhood tavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the door: Nicky embracing the owner, a beefy man nam Georgie. People coming and going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky, God bless. You're well? Your family's well? That's all that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I love this guy. Be good. Stay well. I'm serious: Give my best to everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faces lining the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV images from the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People at tables standing occasionally for a better look the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 Nicky sits facing Toyota and Matthew. A young waiter is placing their food on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if somebody comes in here right now and shoots you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place becomes famous. Tour buses. Blind people feeling around for bullet holes in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see what you're doing, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're charming the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Toyota. He asked me a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie Lazzaro. Coming down the courthouse steps every day in the media. Children see this. They think you're the Secretary of the Treasury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my cousin, Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 The actor Peter Redmond and the director Jack Haskins. A second actor, who is about fifteen, witnesses the exchang
