dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it feel comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does what feel comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 People cluster around TV sets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raucous noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter with a tray of food standing transfixed, watchin the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is now sitting next to Matthew and they are watchin the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like to shoot somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I respect a kid who does his homework in a taxi. But let's put a lid on the questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, tell him. Tell the truth. Tell him how you feel, shooting a piece of hot metal in somebody's flesh who was once a child, who was once the same age as this boy. Somebody's flesh who was innocent once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's complicated. It's a whole life. A person doesn't commit an act of violence out of nowhere. There are strong forces at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV audio: derisive shouts from the stadium crowd directed

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: Red Sox players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dew-eeey! Rog-errr!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar crowd picks up the chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV images. The Red Sox have scored and lead 2-0.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 Nicky stands to see the action better. His jacket swings and Toyota sees the revolver tucked into his waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 eople seating themselves in the orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noise from the tavern TV continues to be heard from the subjective viewpoint of a man in the theater who has a miniature TV and earphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven Schwimmer in an aisle seat in the orchestra. He se Paisley sitting in the theatre some distance away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: House lights go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures hurrying down the aisle. An usher leading a y woman. The woman is Laurel Rogan, Nicky's daughter, weari her headset antennas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel squeezes past some people and takes her seat, and Steven, sitting three rows back, watches her with interes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtain comes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 Cheering from the bar crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is a little disheveled. He has finished his dinner is eating from Toyota's plate finishing and watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a family man, Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife and daughter. My father's still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY(cont'd) He outlives me, starting tonight. Because the Mets just tied the score. It was only a matter of time, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An how many years does it take a person to make his family safe and secure and happy, and then in one dumb moment, what does he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know Toyota. What does he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the people he hurts the most are the people who love him. Despite who he is and what he does for a living. We're always saying we want to take control of our lives. You don't want to take control. You want to lose control. Jesus knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is standing again but he's not looking at the TV sc this time. His gaze is directed at someone who has just entered the tavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman stands at the entrance, middle-aged and somewhat anxious, looking for someone. She is Lillian Rogan, Nicky wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a complicated subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a simple subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky gestures that he will be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father said you might be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-all after six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you because I want to let you know what's been going on before you read about it in a gossip column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stranded five runners in the first two innings. This will come back to haunt us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be fair-minded, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. What's been going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been talking to a prominent divorce lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How prominent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his own submarine. I'll be getting everything that matters. I'll get New York and I'll get Connecticut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy roars from the bar crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young waiter arrives with menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have whatever she's having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Waiter) I don't want to be responsible for his food. Just a small green salad. And a Perrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring me the bay scallops with mercury poisoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessiree, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of here. I don't want you bringing our food. Send a real waiter.
TV images: action on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowd at the bar. Noise like a massive pulse beat. Bar cr picks up chant from stadium crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rog-errrr! Dew-eeey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 Dinner has arrived with a bottle of wine. A cigarette bur in the ashtray in front of Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening night, Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is my fault. I took unfair advantage of your patience and understanding. You understand me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's always been my problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you've been extremely patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why, don't you? Because I am patient, chain-smoking Lillian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smoked because I smoked. We were falling in love, remember? I used to see certain movies only because you had seen them. I wanted to see what you saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went because you went. You smoked because I smoked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very lovely actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Laurel wants us to be honest and open. Let's be open with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN Be open with me. I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY There may be things you'd rather not know about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN I want to know. We haven't talked this way in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I had an affair -- are you sure you want to hear this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN Joanne Bourne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Alma Wetzel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN Nicky, no. This is insupportable. How could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I'm a man. She's, you know, a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN She's my gynecologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lillian begins to weep lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I am really, deeply sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN It violates so many trusts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY It was an animal thing. No real intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LILLIAN I never thought of Dr. Wetzel as having a sex life outside the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it in the office. She thought her apartment was too impersonal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad we're having this talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel great. I feel impeccably alive. I'm elated. Eat something. Please. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moans from the bar crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scoreboard: Red Sox lead 3-2 in the seventh inning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 Nicky with one arm raised, hailing a taxi. He and Lillian kiss sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up and Lillian gets in. She and Nicky hold h through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look awful, sweetheart. Get a haircut. Get a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street, the man in the cutaway is dancing with doll. The tape machine plays, "In the Wee Small Hours of Morning."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Nicky rejoins Toyota and Matthew. He carries the wine bot and his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great game. Red Sox are winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're always winning. Until they lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your problem is you take the easy way out. Losing is easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winning is easy. Losing is complicated. It's a lifetime's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be work but it's not honest work. Faith is the real work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clemens has a blister. Look. They're pinch-hitting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Greenwell comes up to hit for Clemens. Two pitches, strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a twenty-four-game winner. He pitches seven solid innings. We scratch out a one-run lead. Of course he gets a blister. Of course they put up Greenwell even though Baylor's sitting on the bench. Of course Greenwell strikes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third pitch. Greenwell strikes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made him strike out. You wished it on him. You want to lose. It's too hard for you to believe in something. It's hard to have faith. It's hard Nwork to trust somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reciting) "It looked extremely rocky for the Boston nine that day."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid to risk believing. Believe in them. Believe in your self. Take a risk. It will humanize you as a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you believed, you wouldn't be walking around with a handgun in your belt. What does that tell me? You want to make the night come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: iew from the wings. Jack Haskins and Renee Simon looking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage. Peter Redmond as the Father sits at the end of sofa. The fifteen-year-old actor who plays the Son approa him, sitting on a footstool and leaning close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always thought a night's sleep is what you get for a hard day's work. But these last weeks I lie there helpless. Hour after hour. I've come close to praying for the first time since I was your age. Pray to God to put Sme out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to the doctor again, Pop. He said she's not getting any better. He wants to talk to you. I think he means right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stares at the Son, a look of desolation slowly ente his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wings, Renee looks at Jack. She is equally desolat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 Laurel in the audience leans forward, waiting for the nex line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: teven Schwimmer watches, giving nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 eter staring at the Son. The Son looking increasingly bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of coughing in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 Renee takes a newspaper off a chair, offers a section to Jack, keeps the rest for herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8    Sound of coughing intensifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Boisterous noise from the bar crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two women exchanging high fives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scoreboard: 3-3 after nine innings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 Nicky is finishing his wine. Matthew is next to him, standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it and you'll believe it. Life is good. Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to say it because my whole life may depend on these next few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak it like it's real. Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raucous, mocking cries from the Bar Crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hen-duuu! Hen-duuu!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dependable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dependable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dependable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see what Henderson does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave Henderson stands at the plate to lead off the Red So tenth. 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 A real waiter arrives -- obese, slow-moving, with hair curling out of his ears -- and he brings ice cream for Matthew, coffee for Toyota and a stinger for Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, I get a waiter who doesn't know "Macbeth".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I know you, don't I? I seen you on a poster in the theater district. I'll think of your name in just a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky lifts his hand to stop the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hen-duuu!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a moan and deep silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky disengages from the altercation and looks at the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave Henderson has hit a home run and the Red Sox now lea 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toyota and Matthew are jubilant, and Nicky is quick to jo them. It is the only lively table in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dependable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball is life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Red Sox push across another run when Barrett singles, driving home Boggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy your ice cream, kid. When you're an old man it'll come back to you. The same deep sweet soft toothy taste. And you'll remember where you were and what you saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scoreboard shows: Red Sox 5, Mets 3, going into the last the tenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 he theater is nearly emptied out. A few people still head toward the exits. Laurel Rogan remains seated, wearing he headset, listening to the ball game. She is concentrating deeply, fists clenched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one other person is still seated, three rows back. I Steven and he is looking intently at Laurel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house lights dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 Toyota, Matthew and Nicky are huddled closely, watching t screen. Matthew is seated now and Nicky leans over him fr behind, framing the boy's head in his hands so that Matth attention will be directed unswervingly to the action on screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar crowd is somber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky drops his mob accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is something no one has been privileged to see in almost seventy years. Very few people now alive can say that they have seen what you are about to see, Matthew. The Red Sox win a World Series. This is deeply, intensely personal. All the mistakes I've made, all the envy, fear and violence that's encased in this little envelope we call a person -- all washed away in the next few minutes. And your grandmother knows why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because God loves a winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He used to love losers. But the laws of physics changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backman flies out to Jim Rice. One out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backman flies to Rice. It's like a beautiful song lyric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hernandez flied out to Henderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the times I died when the Red Sox lost an important game they should have won. All the awful things I said to my mother and father. To Tmy wife and daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because faith is rewarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 Attendants putting plastic in front of the lockers to pre champagne damage. Camera crew setting up. Men wheeling th twenty cases of champagne into the clubhouse. A man peeli foil from the tops of the bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the failures, all the fatalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter singles to left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar crowd remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more out. One more out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell singles to center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slight stirring among the bar patrons. A few people, abou exit, return to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Frankie. Just a little touch of suspense. Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball is life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more little out. A nubber. A pop-up. All year long, thousands of outs. We want one more little out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knight singles to right center. Carter scores and Mitchel goes to third. The score is 5-4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole tavern is rocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's a test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a test all right. They're bringing in Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Stanley trots in from the bullpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Stanley. It's the Steamer. Fate has spoken to this man in the depths of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurting my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky releases his grip on Matthew's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar crowd begins to chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mookie, Mookie, Mookie, Mookie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mookie Wilson stands in against Bob Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still winning. That's what counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First pitch to Wilson -- he swings and misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence from the bar crowd, cheers from Nicky's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second pitch to Wilson -- he fouls it off. No balls, two strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound begins to fade. Wilson fouls off a pitch. Wilson ta a ball, outside. Wilson fouls off another pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolute, unnatural silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley prepares to throw. The silence suddenly breaks an for the first time we hear the TV Announcers clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sox are one pitch away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One pitch away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley's getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 Nicky recognizing the line from his play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is charged with excitement, hearing the line as a favorable sign, a positive connection between the play an the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley winds up and throws. It's a wild pitch. Mitchell comes in from third with the tying run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar crowd erupts in cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 Shock and dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. It's a tie game. We can still win it next inning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky drinks his stinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mookie, Mookie, Mookie, Mookie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the time. Trust in people. Believe in life. Faith is hard work. Don't give in. Don't give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust your team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley delivers to Wilson. Sound fades away. Action is super slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson swings and hits a bouncing ball toward first base. Stanley moves off the mound to cover first. Wilson drops bat and races down the line. Bill Buckner, the first base ranges to his left to field the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 Nicky watches as if in a trance. Complete silence around He is separate from everybody else, the only clearly defi figure in a group of shadowy and indistinct people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky's viewpoint. An image of Bill Buckner in silvery li expanding out of the TV screen to fill the larger environment. Moving soundlessly in slow motion, Buckner fields the bouncing ball and heads toward the bag. He bea Wilson to the base by an eyelash and the inning ends with teams tied at 5-5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frozen moment: Buckner holding his glove hand aloft, the securely gripped. In the drama of the moment, Buckner see to be crying out a word or name, but his face is twisted tension and exertion and we can't make out what he is say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 Laurel Rogan, seen from behind, is somewhat slumped in he seat. She turns off the radio, removes the headset and ri She moves along the row toward the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She appears to be the only person in the theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves trudgingly up the aisle toward the exit. At the head of the aisle she is startled by a figure standing in dimness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Steven Schwimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. Sound of the cleaning crew in th lobby and then a door opening at the rear of the orchestr Light from a flashlight plays across the seats and walls. beam hits Laurel first and then Steven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beam holds on Steven. What Laurel sees is a strikingl handsome young man, dramatically lighted . He takes off h dark glasses, so she can see his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 102 Cramped space. Nicky at the washbasin, disheveled but hap washing his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One man at the urinal. SECOND MAN behind him, waiting his turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky drying his face with a paper towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND MAN Scintillating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST MAN I still don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Have to hurry back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND MAN Hurry back. Hurry back to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Eleventh inning. What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST MAN (zipping up) I think you're a little confused. Nothing personal friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST MAN What are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Yes. What are you implying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man approaches the urinal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND MAN Game six is history,pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY You're not making sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST MAN We're not making sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND MAN Did you see Mookie hit the ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Of course I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST MAN Did you see the winning run score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not making sense. Make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky throws his paper towel at the men. No one moves. Th are trying to interpret this action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're implying I missed something. What did I Fmiss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed the boat, Popeye the Sailorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky charges the men. He and the First Man wrestle each other into the stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold him till I zip up, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky and the First Man are grappling in the stall. Secon Man hurriedly washes his hands at the basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball is life. Life is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al three men in the stall, wrestling. Nicky has one foot the bowl as someone's elbow strikes the handles and the toilet flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is slowly breaking up. A few people still clust near the TV sets, which are showing replays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is standing alone near a small set at the back on t room. His clothing torn and stained. One shoe and pants l dripping wet. A bruise on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is watching a replay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson hits the ball. It bounces twice, then goes under Buckner's glove. Knight scores from the third with the winning run. A 6-5 victory for the Mets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main light in the tavern goes out. The TV sets keep replaying Buckner's error. Regular speed, slow motion, co black and white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky stands in the darkness, brooding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 The condemned building where Steven Schwimmer lives. The street is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Laurel on the sofa. He is unbuttoning her blou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sources of light. A candle on the coffee table. The s TV set on the counter -- showing a newscast, with sound turned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't you tell me your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only our first date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven undoes the last button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm willing to tell you my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Names are incredibly intimate. We barely know each other. Trust me on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She decides she will trust him. They kiss softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell me what you thought of the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First you tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliantly moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to remove his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packs an emotional wallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flat-out hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together they get his jacket off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you majoring in theater criticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel sees the shoulder holster and gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Criminology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're wondering about the firearm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This building is not secure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all over the sofa, working on the removal of Steven's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 Nicky makes his way past the debris. The front door is go the inner door smashed and battered -- door knobs gone an locking mechanism ripped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts up the stairs past a dead or sleeping body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 On the sofa, Laurel is straddling Steven, whose shirt is almost completely off, exposing his bulletproof vest. Lau is blouseless and barefoot, with her unzipped skirt still and her bra dangling from one shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have this thing where I have to know a person is being honest with me before, you know, I can feel completely free to be myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're strangers in the night. The last thing we want is honesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mystery. Deception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deception isn't something I personally consider sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's sexy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing who a person is. Down deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if the truth about a person is sad or depressing or shocking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't even tell me your name. What's shocking about a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven maneuvers himself into a sitting position so that and Laurel face each other at equal height and at close quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if the truth requires a certain adjustment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven begins removing the cosmetic putty around his naturally shallow chin. He uses Laurel's hair clip to scr his jaw clean. Then he peels off his fake mustache. And borrows Laurel's dangling bra cup to wipe the bronzing ag off his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 108 Nicky stands with his back to Steven's door. His gun is o He holds it up near his face, muzzle pointed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the gun as if it had feelings and personality and he speaks to it as to a sympathetic friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to go to the movies all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY(cont'd) I saw a hundred situations like this. A man and a gun -- and a locked door. Lee Marvin or Steve McQueen. And I used to say to Lillian because we went to a hundred movies that we saw together or that I saw because she had seen them, and I'd say, `Watch him kick in the door with one kick,' And it might be Steve McQueen or Jeff Chandler, holding the gun up like this, and he would turn and kick the door and it would fly open at once, and I would say to Lillian, `How completely phony. Whoever made this movie has no idea how hard it is to kick in an actual door in real life.' I still love Lillian. But it's not easy to kick in a door. I knew they would lose and they lost, so what are we so upset about? They lost tonight, they'll lose tomorrow. It's written on the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 09 Laurel is on her feet, backing away slightly. Steven remo his shoes and stands in his stocking feet, noticeably sho than he'd been earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to unstrap the bulletproof vest, causing Laurel retreat further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These wives named Lillian. I used to say to her, `You don't kick a door once or twice and expect it to open. It's only in the movies a man can kick in a door with such amazing ease. Because a real door requires a tremendous and prolonged pounding before it finally gives way.' He's a great player...how could that ball go through his legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky turns, steps back and kicks the door. It opens at o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 Steven and Laurel are briefly immobilized by shock as the door comes flying open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky moves toward the candle-lit couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel realizes who he is and stands by the sofa. She zip her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky is trying to understand what he sees, then he gets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Laurel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky holds his gun hand aloft, repeating the image of Bi Buckner with the baseball in his glove -- Nicky's hallucination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Nicky issues a cry, a sound from the time before hum acquired language. It is the audible anguish of his life, from the fetus onward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear what he is saying in overlapping echoes and we realize he is crying out a name. We recognize the look on face and the formation of syllables on his lips as elemen we'd seen earlier -- on Buckner's face when he shouted something as he made N the "third out" of the tenth inning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ste-vennnn Schwim-merrrr!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel reacts with horror to the revelation of Steven's identity. She rearranges her bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky stumbles, drops his gun. It goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven flees toward the shadows at the back of the loft, hand moving toward the gun in his shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky picks up his gun and begins to stalk him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven fires twice striking a nearby lamp. The room is da now. Lit only by the blue glow of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV sports roundup, which has been showing football highlights, has switched to baseball -- highlights of the Sox-Mets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky reaches Laurel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY (crying out) This is my daughterrrrr!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is wide-eyed at the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL I don't think he knew, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky sees the photo of Steven and his cat. He shoots twi blows it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Daddy, I'm sorry. But he was so beautiful. I trusted him. When I saw what he really looks like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice from shadows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN (OS) Am I really so deeply repugnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Go home, Laurel. Tell your mother I will be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky walks toward Steven's voice, toward the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY You're going to die. You're a dead man. You're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices Laurel following behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Look. I'm sorry you keep running into dishonest men. But you're only eighteen. We can still turn it around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Except I won't have a father anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I'll see you all the time. I'll get a place right nearby. One room. No distractions. We'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shouts into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel puts her hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL What will we talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky sees one of the New York Magazine ads, Steven Schwimmer's face mounted on the cardboard. He fires three times, wiping out Schwimmer's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Will I believe you when you tell me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY There's nothing left for me to lie about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky starts into the darkness only to see Steven emerge the shadows, his gun lowered. Oddly, he seems distracted something on another part of the room. He is looking at t TV set on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky watches him approach the kitchen area. He follows, raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven sits on a stool to watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky approaches warily, his gun aimed at Steven's head, which is blue-lit by the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY You're dead. I see you on a morgue slab drained of all fluids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel follows at a distance to see what they're so interested in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky puts the gun muzzle flush against Steven's temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I see the outline of your body in chalk on this very floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL (whispering) Daddy, wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is watching slow-motion footage of Bill Buckner missing the slow roller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN Then they lost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Why does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN If they lost tonight, they'll lose tomorrow. It's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY Why do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN They're my team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY No. They're not your team. They're my team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky cocks the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN They're my team, too. I grew up on Boyleston Street. Right by Fenway Park. I went to fifty or sixty games a year. All by myself. I was one of those kids with scabby elbows. I called out to the players. `Look over here. Hi, I'm Steven. My parents are divorced.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I went to college in Boston so I could be near the Red Sox. I took summer classes and the cut them to go to the game. My wife is from Boston. Lillian Ziegler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN The Red Sox were my world. I surrendered my existence to a team that couldn't win the big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY If you're such a devoted fan, why were you at the play tonight instead of the game? Answer carefully. This is important. You could have gone to the theater last night. There was no game last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN Because I can't bear to watch. When they lose, I die inside. It's like some little person named Steve just crumples up and dies. I wait for the scores. I still die, hearing the scores, but it's over in a second. I can't survive the game pitch by pitch, inning by inning. I've done it too many times. And I can't do it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky lowers the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY I was six years old the day Pesky hesitated throwing home and Slaughter scored all the way from first. That's when I knew the Red Sox were my team. Pity and terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN When I traveled through Asia this summer, I went to tremendous trouble and expense to rent a car with a phone so I could call up Sports Phone in New York and get the scores. I drove through the war in Afghanistan calling Sports Phone like every hour on the hour, for updates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY What about my play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL Yes. And no more evasive tactics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN It's your best play, Nicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL See, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN I've seen it twice. I went back tonight to be sure. It's a brave and honest piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN An artistry and sensitivity you've never shown before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY And you're not saying that because of the gun in my hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN You're out of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky points the gun at the palm of his own left hand and pulls the trigger. A click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREL See, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN And Peter Redmond helped immensely. These pauses were exquisitely timed. He made us wait and wait. He built a gorgeous tension and suspense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICKY We worked very hard on the pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky places it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN I called Sports Phone from Lhasa, Tibet. Freezing in my little rented Fiat. Sheep on a hillside. Rocky debris dating back millions and millions of years, from the time the Himalayas thrust up when the plates of India and Asia collided. Red Sox 3, White Sox 2. A moment in the history of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicky takes Steven's head and moves it tenderly against h chest. When Nicky releases the head, he has Steven's toup in his hand. He looks at it briefly, then hands it to Lau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 A yellow taxi comes speeding past, moving eastward on 48t Street. We see it from various perspectives and elevation It is a large checkered cab, the only thing moving in the night. Steam comes billowing from funnel vents. The taxi catches every light just before it turns red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 113 Nicky is driving, his face showing intense satisfaction. Laurel sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driver's name plate ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver sits in the middle of the rear seat, looking somewhat nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 The taxi crosses Park Avenue, speeding past the bronze st of a man hailing a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It approaches First Avenue, where a road divider bisects thoroughfare. Nicky swings into a sharp turns, barely averting contact with the divider, and stops abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three doors open. On the empty street, Nicky hands the dr a wad of bills. Then he and Laurel step over the divider. puts his arm around her shoulders and they cross the aven to the glass tower where they live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun begins to climb out of the East River.
